TextView.android:text: The Benaki Museum of Greek Culture in Athens will tell you Greek history through artworks and collectibles from the 6th century BC, ancient Greece and Greco-Roman civilization, to the years of the Byzantine Empire, the establishment of the Greek state in the early 19th century and even later. The Benaki Museum, founded and endowed in 1930 by Antonis Benakis in memory of his father Emmanuel Benakis, is housed in the Benaki family mansion in Athens in a beautiful neoclassical building directly opposite the National Garden and the building of the Greek Parliament and is certainly one of the most popular museums in Athens. Since then, tens of thousands of other works representative of Greek history have been added, including jewellery, ceramic objects, marble portraits, manuscripts, religious icons, household utensils, clothes and textiles. Today, the Museum houses over 100,000 objects from Greek history from prehistoric to modern times, hosts temporary exhibitions and maintains a state-of-the-art conservation and restoration workshop. Its reopening in 2000 led to the creation of satellite museums focused on specific collections, allowing the main museum to focus on Greek culture throughout the country's history. Scattered in various locations, the museum is among the most important cultural institutions in Greece and showcases the many eras, cultures and civilizations that have influenced Greece's development. The result is a museum that uniquely tells the story of Greece from the Neolithic period to the 20th century and highlights Greek culture as a continuous evolution rather than a series of isolated, disconnected events.
